neofriends.siteDescription: my favourite is reading through sadgrls manifesto and new old web pages. sadgrl has a bunch of fun projects on the go so be sure to check them out. a fun site to explore and get lost in.
a whimsical collection of shrines, dreams and other nostalgic stuff. my favourite is to read the meomoirs which recount memories of a web of yesterday.
a wonderfully crafted homepage full of flashing glittery graphics.
another whimsically styled homepage with shrines, graphics, and other web goodies to explore and download.
self described symphonic metal & midi romance. packed full of homemade music and short stories to explore.
complete with an esoteric design, a homepage full of poems, original graphics and essasy.
cleverly put together! love the punk show bathrooms page.

ownWeb.author: victoriadrake
ownWeb.siteDescription: victoria explores the joys of creating your own personal website.

this page is part of an online course run through the hyperlink acadamy. displayed here are the results of the participants lovingly hand crafted projects from the course. some interesting sites to explore.

interestingArticles.author: Pop Punk & Linguistics
interestingArticles.siteDescription: a  linguistics professors analysis of the american pop punk accent. great read.

interestingArticles.author: The Rise & Fall of Internet Art Communities
interestingArticles.siteName: The Rise & Fall of Internet Art Communities
interestingArticles.siteDescription: a deep dive into the rise and fall of art communities of the early web.

interestingArticles.author: david siegel
interestingArticles.siteName: the web is ruined and i ruined it
interestingArticles.siteDescription: a very deep dive into a time in the 90s where the web changed for better or worse. read it and decided for yourself.

digitalGardens.author: Tanya Basu
digitalGardens.siteName: Digital gardens let you cultivate your own little bit of the internet
digitalGardens.siteDescription: a look into people who are creating and cultivating their own digital gardens online.

digitalGardens.author: Joel Hooks
digitalGardens.siteName: my blog is a digital garden, not a blog
digitalGardens.siteDescription: joel takes us through how his blog is not in fact a blog, but a digital garden. it's different. really.

digitalGardens.author: Maggie Appleton
digitalGardens.siteDescription: maggie has put together a great collection of gardeners who are publicly tending theri digital notes on the interwebs. also has a great number of digital garden resources

digitalGardens.author: Tom Critchlow
digitalGardens.siteDescription: tom takes us through the his thoughts and process for building personal wikis to tend to personal knowledge

digitalGardens.author: Chris Aldrich
digitalGardens.siteDescription: list of all wiki related posts, have not explored all of them yet.

digitalGardens.author: rosie campbell
digitalGardens.siteDescription: rosie uses obsidian publish to create her digital garden. public notes and knowledge base featuring articles, quotes, advice and recipes.

linkDirectories.author: kicks
linkDirectories.siteDescription: the final heartbeats of our beloved www. a hand curated list of links in the style of old yahoo. lots of interesting homepages to get lost in.
a web directory and listing for all kinds of websites
not quite a link directory, however it is a great little collection of interesting links to mostly personal homepages.
an archive featuring a huge collection of fandom type content. i don't even know where to begin with this one.
a webring collecting hand-crafted wikis and portfolios. designer, developer focused. 157 listens with some gems in there.
a webring collecting hand-crafted wikis and portfolios. designer, developer focused. 157 listings with some gems in there.

linkDirectories.author: john december
linkDirectories.siteDescription: a rather large, long running, website. includes a hand curated (i think) web directory. wow. so many links to all corners of the world wide web. let me know if you find anything awesome in there.
a decent directory of handmade webpages. some really interesting and clever pages in there.

linkDirectories.author: waylon531
linkDirectories.siteDescription: a decently sized directory with like 98 categories? so many pages to explore!

webLogs.author: laura kalbag
webLogs.siteDescription: laura is a designer who has published a book covering accessibility. she is one part of the small tech foundation. her blog is full of some great interesting stuff.

webLogs.author: patrick collison
webLogs.siteDescription: really simple blog with an interesting range topics making up the content. patrick is very thoughtful. not your typical dev blog...

webLogs.author: sirodoht
webLogs.siteDescription: a few interesting articles, the most interesting to me was the one on ideal blog platforms and the other on the mataroa webring. materoa seems to be a simple blogging engine the author has created.

webLogs.author: scott hanselman
webLogs.siteDescription: looks like an old blogger template. lots of great articles on various topics. i enjoy their yearly developer and power user tool lists.

webLogs.author: elliot
webLogs.siteDescription: a really interesting wild take on how to hand craft your homepage!

webLogs.author: dima
webLogs.siteDescription: a few posts on various developer things. my fav was the 10 things i've learned while building this website, touches on some 11ty topics

webLogs.author: tom hackshaw
webLogs.siteDescription: not sure if i should categorise this one as a blog as it's so much more. a manifesto (which is awesome by the way), a living wiki, a bookshelf (yay) as well as a blog.

webLogs.author: dennis mai
webLogs.siteDescription: a nice looking website where dennis shares a bunch of his projects, webrings and a selection of articles.

webLogs.author: paul graham
webLogs.siteDescription: simple looking website with a heap of content. some really interesting essays amongst a bunch of other stuff.

coolSites.siteDescription: album information, largest music database online. huge market place for music reselling, love it for tracking down vinyl.

huge lyrics database. used to be just rap music, but now offers all genres. use it for checking out what the actualy lyrics are after singing something completely wrong for days after listening to a song.
have used imdb for decades to check out movie infomation, cross reference actresses and check to see if that was actually them in that movie.
an online record store and music community for fans to discover, connect with, and directly support the artists making awesome music.

manifestoSites.siteName: ten commandments of the small internet
manifestoSites.siteDescription: a grassroots internet movement called "the small Internet" is afoot. here are ten commandments that cheapskates would like to see largely obeyed on the small internet.

manifestoSites.siteName: i miss the old internet
manifestoSites.siteDescription: "I miss the internet of the early 1990's."

manifestoSites.siteName: what i learned about the internet by creating my own website
manifestoSites.siteDescription: here are some things cheapskates learned about the internet by creating their own website.

manifestoSites.siteName: sadgirl.online internet manifesto
manifestoSites.siteDescription: we, the people of the internet, have the power to restore it to its former glory.

manifestoSites.siteName: nostalgia is bullshit
manifestoSites.siteDescription: web 1.0 design nostalgia. like all nostalgia, it's bullshit.

manifestoSites.siteName: seven reasons for having a personal website
manifestoSites.siteDescription: there are at least seven reasons you should have a personal website.

manifestoSites.siteName: the return of the 90s web
manifestoSites.siteDescription: in big cultural concepts like music or fashion, things have a way of coming around full circle.

manifestoSites.siteName: making the web fun again
manifestoSites.siteDescription: "ever since I visited my first web site (via a slow modem to a library BBS running a text-based web browser), i have been ceaselessly pondering the nature of the web."

manifestoSites.siteName: the missing hit and the open web
manifestoSites.siteDescription: if it doesn't appear in google's search results, does it really exist?

manifestoSites.siteName: underscores, optimization & arms races
manifestoSites.siteDescription: a dozen years ago, the web started to reshape itself around major companies like google. we can understand the genesis of today’s algorithmic arms race against the tech titans just by looking at a single character.

manifestoSites.siteName: the modern web is becoming an unsuable. user-hostile wasteland
manifestoSites.siteDescription: the question is: at which point do we reach the breaking point?

manifestoSites.siteName: autonomy online: a case for the indieweb
manifestoSites.siteDescription: there is an alternative to corporate bubbles online — it’s called the indieweb. build your own personal websites, control your online presence, and learn on your own terms.

manifestoSites.siteName: a simpler web
manifestoSites.siteDescription: "i prefer websites that are built with simple html, minimal css, and no javascript for read-only web experiences."

manifestoSites.siteName: hunting the nearly-invisible personal website
manifestoSites.siteDescription: the personal website is a somewhat mysterious animal that lives mostly unobserved in the jungle of the internet

manifestoSites.siteName: zeronet and the future of the internet
manifestoSites.siteDescription: until recently, the conventional wisdom was that the internet is beyond the control of governments. how naive the conventional wisdom sometimes is.

manifestoSites.siteName: tell hn: i miss the old internet
manifestoSites.siteDescription: "this is more of a rant i guess. hackernews provides a text box, that's close enough for me."

manifestoSites.siteName: The Rise And Fall Of Grunge Typography
manifestoSites.siteDescription: The Rise And Fall Of Grunge Typography by Sharan Shetty. Hop on the nostalgia train for a second. Think back to the 90s. To Nirvana, Linklater’s Slacker, and the flannel-clad rebels on the run from the 80s. To skateboards...

manifestoSites.siteName: Everyone Should Have Access to the Web
manifestoSites.siteDescription: The World Wide Web Foundation began as a way to bring the web to everyone. In these trying times, it is needed more than ever.

manifestoSites.siteName: When the Web Was Weird
manifestoSites.siteDescription: In the late ‘90s, an obscure site called Superbad pioneered jarringly bizarre, often ugly, but occasionally beautiful web design. It’s taken all this time for the rest of the internet to catch up.

manifestoSites.siteName: A Love Letter to Net.Art
manifestoSites.siteDescription: In an interview for her book Internet Art in 2004, writer Rachel Greene had this to say about why she felt...

manifestoSites.siteName: To Mend a Broken Internet, Create Online Parks
manifestoSites.siteDescription: We need public spaces, built in the spirit of Walt Whitman, that allow us to gather, communicate, and share in something bigger than ourselves...

manifestoSites.siteName: The Rise and Fall of Internet Art Communities
manifestoSites.siteDescription: Zany, early creative communities like DeviantArt and conceptart.org have been steamrolled by homogenous social media platforms.

manifestoSites.siteName: The year we wanted the internet to be smaller
manifestoSites.siteDescription: Why tiny, weird online communities made a comeback in 2017.

manifestoSites.siteName: Exit Feeds, Enter Community
manifestoSites.siteDescription: Information floods the internet. You can't control it, but it must be controlled for you to absorb it. It is primarily controlled through infinite feeds of content on social media...

manifestoSites.siteName: He Created the Web. Now He’s Out to Remake the Digital World
manifestoSites.siteDescription: Tim Berners-Lee wants to put people in control of their personal data. He has technology and a start-up pursuing that goal. Can he succeed?

manifestoSites.siteName: One Startup’s Vision to Reinvent the Web for Better Privacy
manifestoSites.siteDescription: Blockstack’s system would let you control your own personal data—for example, by revoking a site’s access to it...

manifestoSites.siteName: Make your own independent website
manifestoSites.siteDescription: How to make 2021 the year of the independent web....

manifestoSites.siteName: The Organic Web
manifestoSites.siteDescription: People talk about growing communities and growing brands, but does anyone talk about growing a website?

manifestoSites.siteName: This used to be our playground
manifestoSites.siteDescription: There was a time when owning digital space seemed thrilling, and our personal sites motivated us to express ourselves. There are signs of a resurgence, but too few wish to make their digital house a home...

manifestoSites.siteName: Why can't I write code inside my browser?
manifestoSites.siteDescription: So I can write code inside my spreadsheet, but not inside my browser? WTF!

manifestoSites.siteName: The Developer's Dystopian Future
manifestoSites.siteDescription: I was always a worrier, but I used to be a young worrier. Now I am not so young. I still find things to worry about. I find myself more and more concerned about my future as a developer.

manifestoSites.siteName: It’s Time to Get Personal
manifestoSites.siteDescription: Is it just me or does nobody have their own website anymore? OK, some people do. But a lot of these sites are outdated, or just a list of links to profiles on big tech platforms. Despite being people who build websites, who love to share on the web, we don’t share much on our own sites.

manifestoSites.siteName: It’s Time to Get Personal
manifestoSites.siteDescription: People who grew up with the internet of the 1990s probably remember forums — those clunky, lo-fi spaces where people came together to argue about cars, cycling, video games, cooking, or a million other topics. They had their problems, but in retrospect the internet of those days felt like a magical land of possibility, not a place for organizing pogroms.

manifestoSites.siteName: Let's bring Fan Sites and webrings back!
manifestoSites.siteDescription: In the days before the web was mainstream, it was a place of creation. First for education, then for every random idea that any creator had! As the web transitioned from a network of educational institutions to the consumer force it is today, the early adopters were technologists... AKA geeks!

manifestoSites.siteName: What happened to the ‘old internet’? We used to have so much variety and choice – it’s all collapsed, or has it?
manifestoSites.siteDescription: The internet brings the world into people’s homes, enabling people to interact with worldwide events in a way that television can’t. What's changed?

manifestoSites.siteName: 2015 is the year the old internet finally died
manifestoSites.siteDescription: The old blogosphere is being eaten alive by the rise of social media and the mobile web.

manifestoSites.siteName: There's no place like the old internet
manifestoSites.siteDescription: I started using the internet when I was seven years old. In 2021, it’s not too shocking to imagine a seven year old with unrestricted access to the internet. In 1999, though… different story, different internet...

manifestoSites.siteName: How the Blog Broke the Web
manifestoSites.siteDescription: I first got online in 1993, back when the Web had a capital letter — three, in fact — and long before irony stretched its legs and unbuttoned its flannel shirt. Back when you could really say you were surfing the net...

manifestoSites.siteName: Statistically obsessed
manifestoSites.siteDescription: Measure, analyze, check your stats, take a look at the insights. Whether you are running a business website, a personal blog, a Twitter account or a Facebook page, there is someone breathing down your neck asking about the numbers...

manifestoSites.siteName: The Dark Forest Theory of the Internet
manifestoSites.siteDescription: This is also what the internet is becoming: a dark forest...

manifestoSites.siteName: 404 Page Not Found
manifestoSites.siteDescription: The artifacts of internet life are personal—that is, not professionally or historically notable—and therefore worthless...

manifestoSites.siteName: One Terabyte of Kilobyte Age
manifestoSites.siteDescription: Digging through the Geocities Torrent.

manifestoSites.siteName: The Old Internet Died And We Watched And Did Nothing
manifestoSites.siteDescription: Quick: Can you think of a picture of yourself on the internet from before 2010, other than your old Facebook photos? How about something you’ve written? Maybe some old sent emails in Gmail or old Gchats?

manifestoSites.siteName: The Decade the Internet Lost Its Joy
manifestoSites.siteDescription: What began as cheerful anarchy was devoured by vulture capital and ruthless consolidation

manifestoSites.siteName: About - Baldora Station
manifestoSites.siteDescription: a perfect rant into the pitfalls of the web today, alongside some suggestions for their way forward

manifestoSites.siteName: I miss the old internet - SFFWORLD
manifestoSites.siteDescription: OP comes to the realisation that the Internet has become boring and commercialised. Sparks an interesting conversation.
